coverPage.title: VMware Cloud Migration Assessment
coverPage.subtitle: Migration Analysis and Recommendations for IBM Cloud

executiveSummary.title: Executive Summary
executiveSummary.introduction: This report provides a comprehensive analysis of the current VMware vSphere environment and presents migration options to IBM Cloud. The assessment includes infrastructure inventory, migration readiness evaluation, target platform recommendations, and estimated costs.

keyFindings.title: Key Findings
keyFindings.environmentOverview: The analysis covers the complete VMware environment including all virtual machines, hosts, clusters, and storage infrastructure. This data has been extracted and analyzed to provide accurate migration planning information.

recommendations.title: Recommendations
recommendations.intro: Based on the analysis of the source environment, the following migration approaches are recommended:
recommendations.roksRecommended: ROKS with OpenShift Virtualization is ideal for organizations that want:
roksReasons: Portability: Run workloads on-premises, on IBM Cloud, or across multiple cloud providers using the same Kubernetes-based platform
Unified Platform: Operate both virtual machines and containers on a single infrastructure, enabling gradual application modernization
Future-Ready: Leverage Kubernetes ecosystem tools, GitOps workflows, and cloud-native capabilities as your team evolves
Hybrid Cloud: Consistent operations and workload mobility between environments using Red Hat OpenShift's hybrid cloud capabilities
recommendations.vsiRecommended: VPC Virtual Servers are ideal for organizations that want:
vsiReasons: Familiar Operations: Traditional VM management without requiring Kubernetes expertise or new operational skills
Quick Migration: Straightforward lift-and-shift approach with minimal architectural changes
Simplicity: Each VM maps directly to a VSI instance with well-understood IaaS operations
Lower Learning Curve: IT teams can continue using existing VM management practices and tools

migrationOptions.title: Migration Options
migrationOptions.introduction: Two primary migration paths are available for moving VMware workloads to IBM Cloud. Each option has distinct characteristics that may make it more suitable depending on the organization's goals and requirements.
migrationOptions.comparisonIntro: The following table compares the key characteristics of each migration approach.

roksOverview.title: IBM Cloud Red Hat OpenShift (ROKS)
roksOverview.subtitle: OpenShift Virtualization for VMware Migrations
roksOverview.introduction: Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud (ROKS) is a fully managed OpenShift container platform that enables organizations to deploy, manage, and scale containerized applications. With OpenShift Virtualization (based on KubeVirt), ROKS can also run traditional virtual machines alongside containers on the same platform.

whatIsRoks.title: What is ROKS?
whatIsRoks.content: ROKS provides a managed Kubernetes environment with enterprise features including integrated CI/CD, monitoring, logging, and security. The platform runs on dedicated bare metal infrastructure with local NVMe storage, providing high-performance compute and storage for demanding workloads.

architecture.title: Architecture Overview
architecture.content: ROKS with OpenShift Virtualization uses bare metal worker nodes with local NVMe drives. OpenShift Data Foundation (ODF) provides software-defined storage with Ceph, delivering persistent block and file storage with built-in replication and high availability.
components: Managed OpenShift control plane (provided by IBM)
Dedicated bare metal worker nodes with local NVMe storage
OpenShift Data Foundation (ODF) for persistent storage
OpenShift Virtualization for running VMs as Kubernetes resources
Integrated networking with VPC and IBM Cloud services

items.title: Unified Platform
items.description: Run VMs and containers on the same infrastructure, enabling gradual application modernization.

items.title: Kubernetes-Native Operations
items.description: Manage VMs using familiar Kubernetes tools, APIs, and GitOps workflows.

items.title: High Performance Storage
items.description: Local NVMe drives with ODF provide high IOPS and low latency for demanding workloads.

items.title: Built-in HA and DR
items.description: OpenShift's self-healing capabilities and ODF replication ensure workload availability.

items.title: Path to Modernization
items.description: Migrate VMs first, then containerize applications at your own pace.

considerations.title: Considerations
items: Requires Kubernetes expertise for operations and troubleshooting
Minimum 3-node cluster for ODF storage resilience
Higher base cost due to bare metal infrastructure and storage replication
Best suited for organizations planning application modernization

sizing.title: Recommended Cluster Sizing
sizing.description: Based on the analysis of the source environment, the following ROKS cluster configuration is recommended.
sizing.methodology: Sizing calculations consider CPU requirements (with conservative 1.8:1 overcommit), memory (no overcommit for VMs), and storage (3x replication with ODF operational overhead).

vsiOverview.title: IBM Cloud VPC Virtual Servers
vsiOverview.subtitle: Infrastructure-as-a-Service Migration
vsiOverview.introduction: IBM Cloud VPC Virtual Servers (VSI) provide on-demand compute capacity in a secure, isolated virtual private cloud environment. VSIs offer a straightforward path for lift-and-shift migrations of VMware workloads with minimal architectural changes.

whatIsVsi.title: What are VPC Virtual Servers?
whatIsVsi.content: VPC Virtual Servers are virtual machine instances running on IBM Cloud's next-generation infrastructure. They offer a range of profiles optimized for different workload types, from compute-intensive applications to memory-heavy databases.

architecture.title: Architecture Overview
architecture.content: VSIs run within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC), providing network isolation and security. Each VSI can have multiple network interfaces, block storage volumes, and can be deployed across multiple availability zones for high availability.
components: Virtual server instances with dedicated vCPUs and memory
VPC networking with security groups and ACLs
Block storage volumes (boot and data) with snapshot capability
Multiple availability zones for HA deployments
Integration with IBM Cloud services and VPN connectivity

profileFamilies.title: VSI Profile Families
profileFamilies.description: VSI profiles are organized into families optimized for different use cases:

families.name: Balanced (bx2)
families.useCase: General purpose workloads with balanced CPU and memory

families.name: Compute (cx2)
families.useCase: CPU-intensive applications, web servers, batch processing

items.title: Familiar IaaS Model
items.description: Traditional VM-based infrastructure similar to VMware, reducing the learning curve.

items.title: Flexible Sizing
items.description: Wide range of profiles from 2 vCPU to 128 vCPU to match existing VM sizes.

items.title: Pay-as-you-go
items.description: Hourly billing with no minimum commitment, with discounts for reserved capacity.

items.title: Network Isolation
items.description: Complete network control with VPC, subnets, security groups, and ACLs.

items.title: Enterprise Storage
items.description: High-performance block storage with multiple IOPS tiers and snapshot support.

considerations.title: Considerations
items: Each VM becomes an independent VSI instance
Storage is attached via block volumes, not shared datastores
Maximum profile size of 128 vCPU / 1024 GiB RAM for standard profiles
Operating system licensing may be additional (BYOL or IBM-provided)

sizing.title: VM to VSI Profile Mapping
sizing.description: Each source VM has been mapped to an appropriate IBM Cloud VSI profile based on its compute and memory requirements.
sizing.methodology: Profile selection considers the VM's vCPU count, memory allocation, and memory-to-CPU ratio to determine the optimal profile family (Balanced, Compute, or Memory).

notes.title: Notes and Assumptions
items: Costs shown are list prices without enterprise discounts
Storage costs include the estimated in-use storage, not provisioned capacity
Network egress and additional services are not included
ROKS includes Red Hat OpenShift licensing in the infrastructure cost
VSI costs do not include operating system licensing for non-Linux workloads

nextSteps.title: Recommended Next Steps
nextSteps.introduction: The following steps are recommended to proceed with the migration planning process.

items: Review and validate the migration readiness assessment findings
Remediate identified blockers (VMware Tools, snapshots, RDM disks)
Confirm target platform selection (ROKS or VSI)
Develop detailed migration runbook and testing procedures
Provision IBM Cloud VPC and networking infrastructure
Set up connectivity (Direct Link or VPN) to source environment
Deploy target platform (ROKS cluster or VSI infrastructure)
Configure storage and backup solutions
Select low-risk, non-critical VMs for pilot migration
Execute pilot migration and validate functionality
Document lessons learned and refine procedures
Obtain stakeholder sign-off on migration approach
Execute migration in planned waves
Validate each wave before proceeding to the next
Monitor performance and address any issues
Decommission source environment after successful migration

methodology.title: Assessment Methodology
methodology.content: This assessment was conducted using RVTools data exported from the VMware vSphere environment. RVTools collects comprehensive information about virtual machines, hosts, datastores, networks, and configuration settings. The data was analyzed using automated tools to identify migration readiness issues and calculate resource requirements.

terms.definition: Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud - IBM's managed OpenShift container platform service
Virtual Server Instance - Virtual machine on IBM Cloud VPC infrastructure
Virtual Private Cloud - Isolated network environment on IBM Cloud
OpenShift Data Foundation - Software-defined storage solution for OpenShift
Migration Toolkit for Virtualization - Tool for migrating VMs to OpenShift Virtualization
Virtual CPU - Logical processor allocated to a virtual machine
Gibibyte - 1024^3 bytes, used for memory and storage measurements
Tebibyte - 1024^4 bytes, used for large storage measurements
